I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

comments: Jaime& Alark
Jaime Severino and Alark Saxena

Jaime Severino and Alark Saxena
Jaime
Jaime Severino
Jaime, Alark

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: There seemed to be a lot of confusion related to the logistics of the trip to Cancun. It seemed like we didn't know until the last minute whether we were actually going to attend or not. Also, some of the NGO partners were only partially responsive, and that limited how engaged we could be with the negotiations.
It is a great class and provide valuable opportunities to learn. Strongly recommend!

10, the field trip to Cancun for the COP16 climate negotiation is definitely the highlight of the class, I would suggest all studnts who have interests in climate change issues to participate in this for at least once.
Going to COP16!!
Most obviously, being able to attend the Cancun conference was incredible. The experts, people, and experience I obtained there were simply incredible.
the trip to Cancun, some of the guest lectures
Get the chance to attend COP
Cancun Conference, mock negotiations with Duke
1. Guest lectures by Gary Yohe, Lamumba di-aping and others.2. Mock Negotiations with the Duke team3. And most importantly the trip to COP-16
field trip to Cancun for the COP16 climate negotiations

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: This is a tough one, because it is difficult to prepare for the conference. I think linking students with seperate NGO agencies was a good thing here.
the relationships with the NGOs / course organization
Contact organization: I wish we have firm agreement with contact organizations that students work with during the semester regarding the effectiveness and need of collaboration with students.
1. The tie ups with the NGOs. Some of them are not interested and unresponsive.2. Common agenda for COP
structure of the course, need to be more organized so we would have gotten even more out of it.Also, need more communication with the partnered organizations.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Very very helpful
Good. Instructors were always available.
It seemed like the TAs had a hard time staying on top of the organizational elements of the course, but of course, they were essentially running the course themselves.
Very available, Jaime and Alark, the TAs were always available to help, they did much more than your average TA, especially in Cancun
Instructor and TAs were always available. This is more of a self taught course.
A LOT. All of them are always ready to help you.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This was very important in my larger education since I was able to follow an issue that has come to the forefront of the climate change debate and which is also a big part of my thesis.
learning about the UNFCCC process is very important to my future goals.
Both are great. Especially the TAs are wonderful.
The exposure to the climate change negotiations is a valuable experience and will help me in my career.
yes, it is an eye-opening experience to participate in the UN climate negotiation. The course bridges you to the real world and front line of actions.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To be able to attend to Cancun and gain first hand experience of the UNFCCC process, as well being able to meet experts on climate change from around the world.
for the Cancun trip.
I wanted to learn more about international climate negotiation and organizations by attending the cop.
I wanted to attend the COP 16.
1. Understanding the climate change negotiation process2. Participation in COP 16
personal interet.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
YEs
yes, in that we went to Cancun, but the whole class was a bit disorganized.

Yes, the class was excellent. You get out of it what you put in to some degree, and I was lucky I got a great partner organization. It's like having a part time internship, and takes a lot of time. The mock negotiation was really cool and well run by Gordon, Jaime, Alark,and Adrian. That was the best preparation for the UN conference, I knew what to expect thanks to the mock conference with Duke.
To a large extent yes.
yes, it did.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Yes, and more.
yes
i think I gained a lot during the cop but I disappointed with the collaboration part.
Yes, and then some
Yes.
yes, it did.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advatantages were that I was able to collaborate with my classmates on some deliverables and also during our mock negotiations. Downsides were that I sometimes felt that I was putting in more work than my colleagues on certain assignments.
I had a partner for my internship, it worked well
a good opportunity to learn from each other and produce a high quality assignments in the end.on the other side, it is sometimes hard to coordinate things.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Match up with an NGO and an issue that is passionate to you.
Make sure your NGO partner really wants your help.
Think carefully when choosing the organization that you work with during the semester.
I strongly recommend you to take it and devote yourself as much as possible!

You will need Skype and a good internet connection at home to conference call with your organization, especially if they're located in a different time zone.Plan for the work to be sporadic but intense when there is a task to be done.

Take the course if you wish to participate in the COP!Preferably choose your own NGO to work with. If possible try to be in a country delegation. Take mock negotiations seriously and you'll enjoy the experience.

learn as much as you can about climate change and UNFCCC process before you go to the COP. Also, take full advantage of working with a NGO, ASK for work if you don't get much because they are busy too.
